projects.title: WWF: Double the Tiger - TX2
projects.description:
My MSc thesis at the National Trust for Nature Conservation was part of the global initiative of WWF to double the number of tigers in the wild.

In 2010, when the tiger population had dipped to as few as 3,200, 13 countries that currently or historically had tigers set out to achieve an unprecedented goal: doubling the number of tigers in the wild by 2022. Known as TX2, this is most ambitious global recovery effort ever undertaken for a single species.

WWF’s global tiger program is working to drive TX2 forward.

projects.title: Green Up The City! - Do urban greening initiatives lead to green gentrification in the Netherlands?
projects.description:
Urban greening initiatives have become an important tool for local governments and urban planners to upgrade impoverished neighbourhoods. While green areas are known to contribute to improved health and well-being of residents, there may also be a less positive effect to the greening of neighborhoods.  Worldwide such initiatives have been shown to lead to green gentrification. Green gentrification refers to the displacement of low-income families and small companies as a result of greening initiatives. 

Green gentrification is often associated with environmental justice: having equal access and/or exposure to environmental goods and bads, regardless of race, origin, or socio economic status. Most prior research about environmental justice in the Netherlands  has focused on the distribution of environmental disadvantages, such as exposure to air pollution, rather than the benefits such as access to urban green areas.

The aim of this study is to explore to what extent green gentrification occur in the Netherlands. We investigated whether green gentrification causes environmental injustice. In some occasions, environmental injustice is known as a precursor leading to social inequity in cities.
We defined underlying mechanisms of the process of green gentrification, which is elaborated by three case study neighbourhoods (Amsterdam, Arnhem & Amersfoort). Neighbourhoods were selected based on the recent increase in average income and greening initiatives. In-depth interviews were conducted with residents, local experts and civil servants of the municipality.

We concluded that green gentrification is occurring in the Netherlands, but does not cause environmental injustice to the extent seen in foreign cities, such as New York or Berlin. Gentrification can be triggered by actual greening and as a result of an increase in ‘green’ awareness amongst residents. We did not find any evidence concerning intentional gentrification in the urban planning of municipalities.

volunteer_experiences.description:
Bring the Elephant Home (BTEH) is an active and ambitious elephant research and conservation organisation working from three continents. In collaboration with local communities and scientists, BTEH develops practical solutions to threats and problems.
Together with other members of the Dutch volunteer team I assist BTEH's projects in Africa and Asia and provide a solid base for the organisation in the Netherlands. The volunteer team also works on increasing awareness through education and organises fundraising activities in the Netherlands.
